title: WaveFM: A High-Fidelity and Efficient Vocoder Based on Flow Matching
author: Tianze Luo (Tsinghua University), Xingchen Miao (Tsinghua University), Wenbo Duan (Tsinghua University), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses advanced vocoder techniques that could potentially enhance audio synthesis tasks like voice restoration and music generation in Haohe Liu's research, especially with its focus on improving sample quality and inference speed.
background: Mel-spectrogram conditioned speech synthesis: generating high-quality speech audio from its representation in the mel-spectrogram format.
contribution: WaveFM introduces a reparameterized flow matching model, enhancing both sample quality and generation speed for speech synthesis tasks, achieving superior performance over existing diffusion vocoders.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous vocoders often utilized single loss functions or complex models leading to slower inference and lower quality outputs.
technical_comparison.novelty: This model integrates auxiliary losses and a specialized distillation method, enabling efficient single-step waveform generation while maintaining high audio fidelity.

key_innovation: Utilizes mel-conditioned prior distribution for low variance sampling and incorporates multi-resolution short-time Fourier transform (STFT) loss to better capture audio details.
real_world_impact: By enhancing audio synthesis efficiency and quality, this research could facilitate applications in real-time speech recognition and generation, impacting areas like virtual assistants and content creation.
limitations: The authors note a quality gap between multi-step and single-step models, which could limit usability in high-fidelity applications.

new_terms.mel-spectrogram: **Mel-spectrogram** is a representation of sound that captures the intensity of sound at different frequencies, emphasizing frequencies in a way that reflects human auditory perception.
new_terms.flow matching: **Flow matching** is a technique for training generative models by matching the distribution of generated samples to the distribution of real data, often leading to improved quality in generated outputs.

open_sourcing: Our codes are available at https://github.com/luotianze666/WaveFM
